Department of Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas blasted Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) for implying the department he leads endorses antisemitism in a viral exchange at a congressional hearing on Tuesday.

Hawley was questioning Mayorkas about a DHS employee who reportedly made inflammatory social media posts denouncing Israel after Hamas militants launched a brutal attack there on Oct. 7.

Among a volley of questions, Hawley asked, â€œIs this typical of people who work at DHS?â€ and called Mayorkas â€œdespicableâ€ for not answering his queries.

After several minutes of heated questioning, Mayorkas, who is Jewish, gave a rebuttal. Watch the moment here.

Bad Bunny fans were shocked when they clicked into Ticketmaster and saw the prices for his â€œMost Wantedâ€ tour. The fiasco follows a trend of rising ticket prices since the pandemic, with more demand after quarantine along with inflation.

Fans view Ticketmaster as a necessary evil when they want to see their favorite artists perform; it is the worldâ€™s largest ticket provider. But letâ€™s not forget that artists have a say in what theyâ€™re willing to charge.

Read the full story at our link in bio.

The cast of â€œFriendsâ€ came together on Monday to offer a touching tribute to actor Matthew Perry.

Two days after the actorâ€™s death, co-stars Courteney Cox, Matt LeBlanc, Jennifer Aniston, David Schwimmer and Lisa Kudrow released a statement to People honoring their longtime cast mate:

â€œWe are all so utterly devastated by the loss of Matthew. We were more than just cast mates. We are a family," they said in the joint statement.

"There is so much to say, but right now weâ€™re going to take a moment to grieve and process this unfathomable loss."

Read the full statement at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· NBC via Getty Images Getty Images // ğŸ–Šï¸David Moye

Concert ticket prices were already out of control â€” but Bad Bunny just took it to an entirely new level of ridiculousness.â 
â 
Not long after the artistâ€™s â€œMost Wantedâ€ 2024 tour presale started on Wednesday, fans were criticizing the high ticket prices on social media. Prices for seats in the nosebleeds were $150-$250 on Ticketmaster, depending on the city and before fees, according to people who shared their experience on TikTok. In Miami, a 100-level ticket was $750. Prices for floor seats were even higher, with some reporting $1,000 per ticket.â 
â 
The fiasco follows a trend of rising ticket prices since the pandemic, with more demand after quarantine along with inflation. Taylor Swiftâ€™s concert ticket prices werenâ€™t awful until ticket scalpers started inflating the resale prices. Both BeyoncÃ©â€™s and Drakeâ€™s ticket prices were advertised for one price and then skyrocketed due to Ticketmasterâ€™s â€œdynamic pricing,â€ which inflates prices based on demand.â 
â 
This canâ€™t become the new normal. We desperately need a concert revolution and to stand up against corporate greed. â 
â 
Fans need to band together and stop buying tickets when theyâ€™re overpriced like this. And many Bad Bunny fans did.â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“·ï¸: Getty Images // ğŸ–Šï¸: Cambria Roth

"It has taken me decades to be ready to tell this story," writes HuffPost guest writer Suzanne Heywood. "Until I reached the safety of adulthood and created my own family, I wasnâ€™t able to confront my parentsâ€™ story about my past. In their telling, I was 'privileged.' After all, I grew up on a beautiful boat called Wavewalker, sailing around the world."

"Of course I knew their story wasnâ€™t true," Heywood continues. "Although I had grown up on Wavewalker from the age of 7 for almost a decade, I was trapped there â€” unable to go to school or have friends. While my brother was allowed to help out on deck, I was expected to cook and clean down below for hours each day."

Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Courtesy of Suzanne Heywood

Rep. Mike Johnson (R-La.) was just installed as the new House speaker, and heâ€™s already getting trolled for his anti-LGBTQ+ views by one of his Democratic colleagues.

Although Johnson was elected by a party-line vote of 220 to 209, Democrats chose to nominate House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.) as the speaker â€” and one of them made it personal.

When it came time for Angie Craig (D-Minn.) to voice her choice, she used the occasion not only to vote for Jeffries for the top role, but to pay tribute to a top person in her life: her wife, Cheryl.

Watch the glorious moment at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Getty Images // ğŸ–Š David Moye

Donald Trump stormed out of the courtroom on Wednesday amid testimony from his former attorney Michael Cohen in a New York civil fraud trial concerning the Trump Organization.

The former presidentâ€™s Secret Service agents were caught off-guard and chased after him as he abruptly left the room, according to reporters who were present.

Trump exited the courtroom shortly after Cohen admitted that Trump had never asked him to inflate the numbers on his financial statements.

Once outside, Trump declared to reporters before walking away: â€œThe witness just admitted that we won the trial. And the judge should end this trial immediately.â€

Read more of the developing story in the link in bio. //ğŸ–ŠLydia Oâ€™Connor //ğŸ“·Getty Images

Last year, Justine Lindsay made two of the biggest announcements of her life in one giddy Instagram post: Sheâ€™s transgender, and she had landed herself a spot on an NFL cheerleading squad.

It was more than just a huge personal moment. In joining the Carolina TopCats, who cheer for the Carolina Panthers, Lindsay was becoming the first openly trans athlete in a space known for its problematic relationship with diversity.

There were highs and lows during her first year on the job. Triumphant performances. Coping with harassment, threats and abuse. But as she stepped onto the field for her second season last month, Lindsay was decidedly joyous about the chance to keep on performing.

â€œI love it. Wouldnâ€™t change it for the world,â€ she told HuffPost in an interview on her 31st birthday.

Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“·: Getty Images // ğŸ–Šï¸: Josie Harvey

"In August 1979, a young couple landed on the cover of National Geographic for walking 3,000 miles across America. I was half of that couple," writes HuffPost guest writer Barbara Jo Jenkins. â 
â 
"To the world, we were a fascinating couple, sweethearts of American adventure. Inside, I felt like a fraud." Read more at our link in bio. // Getty Images

WASHINGTON â€• Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) dropped his bid to become the 56th speaker of the House of Representatives on Friday following a vote by his Republican colleagues.â 
â 
Republicans voted against keeping Jordan as their speaker-designee by a margin of 86 to 112, Republicans told reporters. Jordan then accepted the result. Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ–Šï¸ Arthur Delaney // ğŸ“· Getty Images

Hamas has released two U.S. hostages, described as a mother and her daughter, according to multiple reports.

The two people were released Friday â€œfor humanitarian reasonsâ€ in response to Qatari mediation efforts, Reuters reported, citing a spokesperson for the armed wing of the radical Islamist militant group. Read more at our link in bio. ğŸ–Šï¸ Nina Golgowski

In a speech in Israel, President Joe Biden urged Israelis not to repeat the mistakes the United States made following the 9/11 attacks in Israelâ€™s own response to the Hamas attacks that have reportedly left at least 1,400 Israelis dead since Oct. 7.â 
â 
â€œI caution this, that while you feel that rage, donâ€™t be consumed by it,â€ Biden said in public remarks in Tel Aviv. â€œAfter 9/11, we were enraged in the United States. While we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes.â€â 
â 
Bidenâ€™s warning about overreaching in response to a traumatic event may be his most explicit call for Israeli restraint in its war on Gaza. It comes, however, as his administration has squashed public communications that mention â€œde-escalation,â€ â€œceasefire,â€ â€œend to violence/bloodshedâ€ and â€œrestoring calm,â€ according to a HuffPost report. The president has also struck an unflinching pro-Israel stance, moving a carrier strike group off the coast of Israel and promising billions in military aid.â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Getty // ğŸ–Šï¸ Paul Blumenthal

KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip (AP) â€” A massive blast rocked a Gaza City hospital packed with wounded and other Palestinians seeking shelter Tuesday, killing hundreds of people, the Hamas-run Health Ministry said. Hamas blamed an Israeli airstrike, while the Israeli military said the hospital was hit by a rocket misfired by Palestinian militants.â 
â

"On a recent flight, I found myself seated next to a man Iâ€™ll call Rick, who was keen for conversation," writes HuffPost guest writer Nina Vinik.â 
â 
"A self-described '2A [Second Amendment] fanatic' from Texas, Rick grew up with guns and today owns more than 40 firearms. He considers himself a collector, and many of his guns are antiques â€” heâ€™s not interested in assault-style firearms â€” and he makes his own ammunition from recycled casings," Vinik contines. "In short, Rick is a gun guy, and I was interested in his views on gun violence. I explained that I lead a gun violence prevention organization."â 
â 
"Rick was intelligent, well-spoken and rational, and I enjoyed talking with him. But our conversation provides a real-world example of why we should be skeptical of the idea that gun violence will be solved by finding common ground with gun owners."â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Getty Images

Netflixâ€™s fifth season of â€œLove Is Blindâ€ has officially come to an end â€” but a lot was still left unanswered. â 
â 
Netflix producers cut out a whole engagement between Renee and Carter, edited Aaliyah and Ucheâ€™s talk to make it seem like they ended things right after the show, and all-out refused to follow at least one other engaged couple from this season.â 
â 
Then they had the nerve to make a whole compilation of testimonials from cast members talking about how great the show was for them. â 
â 
Thatâ€™s a convenient stunt for a show whose production companies have faced multiple allegations around filming conditions, including a sexual assault lawsuit from this latest season.â 
â 
This season was pretty unsatisfying â€” and there were really only two things that saved it. â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“·ï¸: Netflix

A 6-year-old boy and his mother were stabbed over a dozen times late Saturday morning in an anti-Muslim hate crime, according to police. The child, Wadea Al-Fayoume, was killed.â 
â 
Landlord Joseph Czuba, 71, was charged on Sunday with murder and hate crime for allegedly stabbing Wadea and his mother, Hanaan Shahin, 32, who were his tenants in Plainfield, Illinois.â 
â 
Czuba was charged with two counts of hate crime alongside first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.â 
â 
â€œDetectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the ongoing Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis,â€ the Plainfield Township homicide department said in a statement.â 
â 
Shahin was stabbed over a dozen times but is expected to survive, according to officials.â 
â 
Her son, Wadea, was remembered for his passion for life by Ahmed Rehab, the executive director of the Chicago office for the Council on American-Islamic Relations.â 
â 
â€œHe loved everything, he loved everybody, loved his toys, anything with a ball â€• basketball, soccer. He loved to color; he loved to swing around. He loved his parents. He loved his family and his friends. He loved life,â€ Rehab said.â 
â 
â€œHe has no clue about these larger issues happening in the world. But he was made to pay for it,â€ Rehab added.â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· CAIR // ğŸ–Šï¸ Rowaida Abdelaziz

In news that feels custom-designed to make a generation of television viewers suddenly conscious of their age, the â€œTeletubbiesâ€ Sun Baby is expecting her first child.â 
â 
Jessica Smith â€• whose face regularly appeared wreathed in sunshine on the beloved childrenâ€™s series, which ran from 1997 to 2001 â€• confirmed her pregnancy Wednesday with a pair of ultrasound photos on Instagram.â 
â 
â€œWhen two becomes three,â€ the British actor wrote in the caption, while tagging her partner, Ricky Latham. The couple are expected to welcome their daughter in January.â 
â 
Not surprisingly, the news set off a wave of nostalgia among â€œTeletubbiesâ€ fans, many of whom congratulated Smith in the comments.â 
â 
â€œThe Teletubbies sun baby is having her own sun baby,â€ one person wrote.â 
â 
â€œI strongly believe itâ€™s time for a reboot, and your baby child should follow in your footsteps,â€ another said.â 
â 
Smith, now 27, was just 9 months old when she was cast as the Sun Baby, who summoned the four titular characters at the beginning and end of each â€œTeletubbiesâ€ episode.â 
â 
The role of the Sun Baby remained uncredited until 2014, when Smith was first identified in the media as the iconic character.â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ–Šï¸ @curtismwong // ğŸ“· YouTube/Teletubbies

As Israel escalates its attacks on Gaza, the State Department is discouraging diplomats working on Middle East issues from making public statements suggesting the U.S. wants to see less violence, according to internal emails viewed by HuffPost.â 
â 
In messages circulated on Friday, State Department staff wrote that high-level officials do not want press materials to include three specific phrases: â€œde-escalation/ceasefire,â€ â€œend to violence/bloodshedâ€ and â€œrestoring calm.â€â 
â 
The revelation provides a stunning signal about the Biden administrationâ€™s reluctance to push for Israeli restraint as the close U.S. partner expands the offensive it launched after Hamas â€• which rules Gaza â€• attacked Israeli communities on Oct. 7.â 
â 
The emails were sent hours after Israel told more than 1.1 million residents of northern Gaza that they should leave their homes and shelters ahead of an expected ground invasion of the region. On Thursday, the United Nations said Israel had given Gazans a 24-hour deadline to move to the south of the strip, adding it would be â€œimpossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences.â€â 
â 
Asked about Israelâ€™s evacuation order on Friday, U.S. National Security Council spokesman John Kirby declined to reject or endorse it, calling it â€œa tall order.â€â 
â 
When reached for comment on the directive, a State Department official said they would not comment on internal communications.â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ–Šï¸ Akbar Shahid Ahmed

A BBC Arabic journalist reported on the distressing conditions inside an overwhelmed Gaza hospital that he said contained many of his friends and neighbors.â 
â 
â€œToday has been one of the most difficult days in my career. I have seen things I can never unsee,â€ BBCâ€™s Adnan Elbursh, a Gaza resident, said in the report from Al Shifa, Gaza Cityâ€™s main hospital, posted late Thursday.â 
â 
â€œBodies lay everywhere. The injured scream for help. You can never forget the sounds,â€ he reported.â 
â 
Among the dead and wounded, his cameraman had spotted his friend Malik, Elbursh said.â 
â 
â€œMalik has managed to survive, but his family have not,â€ Elbursh said over footage of his tearful colleague.â 
â 
Elbursh said bodies were being placed outside the hospital on the ground after the morgue reached capacity.â 
â 
â€œYou never want to become the story. Yet, in my city, I feel helpless as the dead were given no dignity and the injured are left in pain,â€ he said.â 
â 
Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza, launched a devastating surprise attack on Israel on Saturday, massacring hundreds of people and taking scores of hostages.â 
â 
Israel declared war on Hamas in response. It has since laid siege to Gaza, which has a dense population of more than 2 million, bombarding the Palestinian enclave with airstrikes and preparing for a possible ground invasion. It has also shut off access to electricity, food, fuel and water in Gaza.â 
â 
The conflict has already claimed over 2,800 lives on both sides. Thousands more are injured.â 
â 
Watch the report at our link in bio. // ğŸ–Šï¸ @josieharvey // ğŸ“· @bbc

When Neta Heiman last spoke to her 84-year-old mother, Ditza, her kibbutz was under fire amid the bloodiest assault on Israel in 50 years. Heiman has since learned Ditza was kidnapped by the Palestinian militant group Hamas and taken into the Gaza Strip â€• and she is determined to give the world three messages.â 
â 
Governments worldwide should push to make sure the Hamas hostages get their medication, Heiman told HuffPost on Thursday, noting that most residents of her motherâ€™s community were elderly people she has known â€œfrom the day I was born.â€â 
â 
Heiman also wants global help for those detainees to be returned to their families.â 
â 
And she believes the U.S. must apply pressure to solve the Israeli-Palestinian dispute for good.â 
â 
â€œI hope the international community will help,â€ Heiman said. â€œThis would be in the interests of everyone.â€â 
â 
Heiman is worried her mother could be affected by Israelâ€™s ongoing bombardment of Gaza, a narrow, tightly packed sliver of land. Israeli airstrikes have repeatedly hit residential neighborhoods there, killing more than 1,500 people, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appears to be preparing a ground invasion. The Israeli military on Friday ordered the evacuation of northern Gaza, which is home to over 1 million Palestinians, in what the U.N. described as an â€œimpossibleâ€ task to carry out without â€œdevastating humanitarian consequences.â€â 
â 
â€œThey are bombing Gaza, and we donâ€™t know where she is and where all the people are,â€ Heiman said, referring to the scores of other hostages. â€œThey may not be in one place.â€â 
â 
Heiman published an essay in the Israeli newspaper Haaretz on Thursday describing how her anger has multiple targets: her motherâ€™s kidnappers but also Israeli politicians whom she blames for not doing enough to support hostagesâ€™ families and for failing to establish peace with the Palestinians.â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Courtesy of Neta Heiman // ğŸ–Šï¸ Akbar Shahid Ahmed and Marita Vlachou

Prince Harry and Meghan appeared in New York today for a special cause: the Archewell Foundation Parentsâ€™ Summit. During the royalsâ€™ appearance on a panel about mental health in a digital age, Meghan called being a mom â€œthe most important thing in my entire life,â€ before looking at Harry and saying â€œOutside of course to being a wife, to this one.â€ ğŸ¥ @carly.ledbetter

A Canada-born Jewish humanitarian who dedicated most of her life to helping Palestinians has gone missing after Hamas fighters attacked Israel over the weekend.â 
â 
Vivian Silver lives near the Gaza Strip in southern Israelâ€™s Beâ€™eri kibbutz. After Hamas fighters launched a surprise attack on Israel on Saturday, the 74-year-old hid at home and communicated with her son over the phone, he told CBC News. She texted him that the militants were in her house.â 
â 
â€œShe has a really great sense of humor, so we joked up until that point,â€ Yonatan Zeigen, who is based in Tel Aviv, told CBC Newsâ€™ Adrienne Arsenault. â€œWe were joking and then we said, â€˜OK, itâ€™s time to stop joking,â€™ and just expressed love for each other, and that was it.â€â 
â 
The attacks by Hamas, the armed group that rules over the millions of Palestinians in Gaza, have resulted in over 900 people killed in Israel, according to the nationâ€™s military. Palestinian officials say that more than 700 people have been killed in sealed-off Gaza and the occupied West Bank since Israel launched massive retaliatory attacks with the support of Western nations.â 
â 
Zeigen told CBC that he does not believe his mother is missing, but instead either dead in her house or among the hostages taken to Gaza by Hamas. Authorities were still reportedly clearing the kibbutz of explosives and have not been able to provide an update on Silverâ€™s whereabouts.â 
â 
Loved ones of Silver have told media outlets that the Winnipeg-born woman dedicated her life to ending the Israeli occupation and is highly regarded by both Israelis and Palestinians as a force who fought for lasting, permanent peace.â 
â 
â€œSheâ€™s a woman of small stature, but in spirit sheâ€™s a giant,â€ Zeigen said on CBC News. Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ–Šï¸ â 
Sanjana Karanth

â€œMy husband Neil and I are polar opposites. Each day unfolds before my eyes, ripe with possibility. Neil, who has already been to the grocery store, dropped off laundry, worked out at the gym, and taken the dog to the vet, is ready to tackle whatever is on my list," writes HuffPost guest writer Marjorie Weidenfeld Buckholtz.â 
â 
â€œI am barely awake. What list? I groggily wonder.â€â 
â 
â€œNeil â€• what a guy. In addition to his many duties, he is the manager of all things me.â€ â 
â 
â€œHe appears at the threshold of the porch juggling my coffee and a Danish in one hand, my handwritten list in the other. It is the â€˜to-doâ€™ inventory I had outlined the night before. Damn.â€â 
â 
â€œâ€˜Will I ever learn?â€™ I ask myself.â€â 
â 
â€œâ€˜Why is HE like this?â€™â€ I wonder. Weâ€™re from the â€˜Free to Be You and Meâ€™ generation, and we equally shared all the duties involved in running our chaotic family of four rambunctious kids under the age of 10. He changed diapers, made lunches, bought groceries, did the laundry, and more. I was the designated talker when it came to home repairs, juggled hapless babysitter schedules and medical appointments, shopped for large appliances, and bought and repaired the cars.â€â 
â 
â€œWhat miraculous alignment of the planets could bring two opposites together... and make them stick together for six decades?â€ â 
â 
â€œRecently, at an anniversary party in a room full of friends and family, Neil toasted our longevity in his favorite language â€” science jargon. Clearly understood by other neuroscientists, it leaves some of us civilians scratching our heads. Rarely does Neil volunteer to speak publicly in his private life, although professionally, as head of Alzheimerâ€™s research for the National Institutes of Health, he gave talks all over the world. At home, he is quite reserved, so I didnâ€™t anticipate what was coming.â€â 
â 
Read Neilâ€™s beautiful answer at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Courtesy of Alison Buckholtz

â€œOne day I was on the StairMaster, doing my thing, when a Black gym employee approached a white guy on the treadmill in front of me and told him to pull his mask back up. He gave her a quick glance, slowly tugged the fabric, then returned his focus to running,â€ writes HuffPost guest writer Delano Burrowes.â 
â 
â€œThere was something about the look I saw him give her: entitlement. Dismissal. Invisibility. It triggered an overwhelming urge in me to wipe the smugness off his face.â€â 
â 
â€œâ€˜Hey! Didnâ€™t she tell you to put your f**king mask on?â€™â€ I was somehow off the StairMaster, standing next to the man, and speaking at a volume I never used.â€â 
â 
â€œI expected, wanted, and needed an apology â€” for so much. Instead, I got a version of the glance heâ€™d given the employee. I wasnâ€™t about to let it end like that, but then I saw past him to the mirror behind the treadmills. I looked crazy.â€â 
â 
â€œHow did I become this person? I asked myself. Yeah, heâ€™s probably an a**hole, but gyms are full of a**holes. So what?â€â 
â 
â€œAfter the treadmill interaction, I thought about another gym incident, also regarding a mask, a few months before. I was in the weight room when I heard, â€œâ€˜Hey, bro, can you put your mask over your nose?â€™â€â 
â 
â€œThe Black guy on the butterfly machine looked over at the white guy talking to him. â€œNah. Iâ€™m good,â€ he said.â€â 
â 
â€œâ€˜Huh? You do know thereâ€™s a pandemic, right?â€™ the white guy asked.â€â 
â 
â€œIt escalated into an adrenaline-fueled argument, and a Black staffer was asked to intervene.â€â 
â 
â€œI knew the conflict going on in the staff memberâ€™s head: 'How can I side against another Black person in this space?' They averted their eyes and walked away.â€â 
â 
â€œI had barely talked to the other Black guy in all the years Iâ€™d seen him around, but now we looked at each other and slowly nodded.â€â 
â 
â€œWhy did I act like that then and now had a completely opposite reaction? It made no sense, except it did.â€â 
â 
Read the full essay at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Courtesy of Jules Arribillaga

A sizable and mischievous pig is on track for a new life after spending days disrupting traffic and damaging property in Aurora, Colorado.â 
â 
Fred, as heâ€™s now named, was first spotted on the streets on Sept. 24, when the city received â€œits first call about a pig in traffic,â€ city spokesperson Michael Brannen told HuffPost in an email.â 
â 
But Fred evaded animal control officers that afternoon, and over the next few days the city received multiple sightings of the pig, mostly â€œtrotting near traffic and digging up landscaping.â€â 
â 
At some point, Fred gained a rope lasso seen trailing around his neck, indicating that someone had tried and failed to catch him. Itâ€™s unclear who the attempted captor was, since Brannen clarified the lasso was not the doing of animal services.â 
â 
On Sept. 27, Fredâ€™s troublemaking â€• dubbed a â€œmulti-day crime spreeâ€ by local news outlet Denver7 â€• came to a close. But the pig didnâ€™t give himself up easily. â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· City of Aurora // ğŸ–Šï¸ Hilary Hanson

Are you approaching job interviews all wrong? In this week's episode of HuffPost's new podcast "Am I Doing It Wrong," co-hosts @noahmichelson and @rajji_f_baby spoke with trusted career coach and psychologist @drorbeaustin to find out what you should and shouldnâ€™t do to ace your next interview. Head to our link in bio to listen to "Am I Doing It Wrong?"

"In the summer of 2022, my husband Chuck and I sent Henry, our 18-year-old son, off to college," writes HuffPost guest writer Elizabeth Kopple. "Heâ€™d overcome so many challenges to get there: attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, anxiety, and difficulty connecting with other kids. As he matured, he gained confidence by participating in cross-country running, drama and debate. He developed a rapport with his peers by listening more and talking less. When he flew to college, he left behind friends from high school, summer jobs and youth groups. He was ready academically and had even earned a merit scholarship."â 
â 
"On Friday, when it was time for me to leave, I placed my hands around Henryâ€™s middle, pressed my right cheek to his chest, closed my eyes and squeezed," Kopple continues. "At that moment, I was embracing every version of my son: chunky baby, curious toddler, zany seventh grader in braces, hungry teenager, all the rest I knew and had known. After one final hug â€” Henryâ€™s signature move â€” I left for the airport."â 
â 
"The following Monday night, around midnight, Chuck and I were awakened by two policemen who told us Henry had been killed."â 
â 
"How is this possible? I helped Henry unpack in his dorm room," Kopple writes. "We put away his jeans, mountains of socks, shower shoes and toiletries, a book he was excited to read called â€œThe Nordic Theory of Everything,â€ Kind bars, and cups of Dr. McDougallâ€™s Black Bean & Lime instant soup."â 
â 
"In an instant, every expectation for our family and our future was obliterated."â 
â 
Read more at our link in bio. // ğŸ“· Courtesy of Elizabeth Kopple

What did summer 2023 have against love?â 
â 
Earlier this week, actor Jodie Turner-Smith filed for divorce from Joshua Jackson after four years of marriage and the birth of a daughter in 2020 â€• making them the latest celebrity couple to call it quits.â 
â 
Other big marital breakups lately? Joe Jonas and Sophie Turner, Joe Manganiello and Sofia Vergara, Britney Spears and Sam Asghari â€• even in-office Canadian head of state Justin Trudeau and his wife, Sophie GrÃ©goire.â 
â 
Divorce attorneys are taking note. Lynda Hinkle, a family law attorney practicing in New Jersey, was most surprised by the news that Jeremy Allen White, the rising star of FXâ€™s â€œThe Bear,â€ and actor Addison Timlin were splitting.â 
â 
â€œIâ€™m sure the pressure of having your career exploding and a rigorous filming schedule makes any preexisting challenges much harder, but how sad that one part of his life was blossoming while another part was dying on the vine,â€ she told HuffPost.â 
â 
Then again, sheâ€™s not that surprised; celebrities are generally pretty frequent divorcers because they can afford to, Hinkle said.â 
â 
But thereâ€™s more at play here, too. The uptick in celebrity summer divorces â€• or early fall, as it is â€• actually does reflect a real seasonal trend in matrimonial affairs. â 
â 
Head to our link in bio for more. // ğŸ“· Damon Dahlen/HuffPost; Getty Images // ğŸ–Šï¸ Brittany Wong

"As a child, my first brush with a ghost wasnâ€™t Casper or some other spook from a childrenâ€™s book. I encountered the real deal in the house we rented in Pennsylvania after my family emigrated from Kuwait," writes HuffPost guest writer Salina Jivani.â 
â 
"It was over a century old, essentially the size and strength of a wet shoebox, and was shadowed by an ominous oak tree in a rundown neighborhood."â 
â 
"My dad, who grew up poor and lost his father as a teenager, had cultivated a knack for stretching every penny he earned. Years before we moved to the U.S., he squirreled away what he could, which helped him get settled in Pennsylvania when a locally headquartered company offered him a job on an H-1 Visa."â

"The timing couldnâ€™t have been more off â€• he left for America when I was 3 and my mother was pregnant with my brother â€• but my parents felt their sacrifices would be well worth the potential opportunities neither of them had been fortunate enough to grow up with.
